claim: The working hours of Americans have increased over time.

supporting.text: Historical data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees in the U.S. have increased since the mid-20th century.

attacks.text: Historical data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees in the U.S. have increased since the mid-20th century.
The data does not account for the rise of part-time employment, which has grown significantly and may offset the increase in full-time working hours.
Even with part-time employment growth, full-time employees still represent the majority of the workforce, so their increased hours dominate the overall trend.
Technological advancements have blurred the line between work and personal time, making historical comparisons of 'working hours' less meaningful.
Studies controlling for technology use still show an increase in measurable work hours, suggesting the trend is real and not just a measurement artifact.

supporting.text: The rise of the gig economy and freelance work has led many Americans to work longer hours to supplement their income.

attacks.text: The rise of the gig economy and freelance work has led many Americans to work longer hours to supplement their income.
Many gig economy jobs offer flexible schedules, allowing workers to choose their hours and potentially work fewer hours than traditional employment.
Flexibility does not necessarily reduce hours; workers may still choose to work longer to maximize earnings, especially in low-paying gig jobs.
Official labor statistics may not fully capture gig economy hours, leading to an overestimation of increased working hours.
Studies using alternative data sources (e.g., time-use surveys) confirm that gig workers often report longer working hours than traditional employees.

supporting.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal life, leading to increased working hours.

attacks.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal life, leading to increased working hours.
Studies show that while technology enables constant connectivity, it also allows for flexible work arrangements, which can reduce overall working hours for some employees.
Flexible work arrangements often lead to employees working longer hours to meet expectations, as the boundaries between work and personal time remain unclear.
The increase in working hours is not universal; certain industries and job roles have seen a decrease in working hours due to automation and efficiency gains.
Even with automation, the pressure to remain competitive often leads employees to work longer hours to manage increased workloads or job insecurity.
The perception of increased working hours may be influenced by survivorship bias, where only those working longer hours report their experiences, while others with reduced hours go unnoticed.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages and rising living costs, have compelled many Americans to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages and rising living costs, have compelled many Americans to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.
Technological advancements and automation have reduced the need for long working hours in many industries, counteracting economic pressures.
Despite automation, many service and gig economy jobs require longer hours due to low wages and lack of benefits, reinforcing economic pressures.
Government policies and labor laws, such as overtime regulations, have limited the extent to which working hours can increase.
Enforcement of labor laws is often weak, and many employers find ways to circumvent regulations, allowing for de facto longer working hours.

supporting.text: Studies indicate that salaried employees in the U.S. are increasingly expected to work beyond traditional 40-hour weeks without additional compensation.

attacks.text: Studies indicate that salaried employees in the U.S. are increasingly expected to work beyond traditional 40-hour weeks without additional compensation.
Many salaried employees now have flexible work arrangements, allowing them to work fewer hours while maintaining productivity.
Flexible arrangements often lead to 'always-on' expectations, blurring the line between work and personal time and increasing total hours worked.
The rise of remote work has reduced commuting time, effectively decreasing total work-related time investment.
Remote workers often report working longer hours due to lack of clear boundaries between work and home life.
Labor statistics show stable average weekly hours for all employees over the past two decades.
Official statistics may undercount unpaid overtime and off-the-clock work common among salaried professionals.

supporting.text: The decline of union representation in the U.S. workforce has reduced collective bargaining power, contributing to longer working hours for many employees.

attacks.text: The decline of union representation in the U.S. workforce has reduced collective bargaining power, contributing to longer working hours for many employees.
Many industries with historically low union representation, such as tech and finance, have seen stable or even reduced working hours due to automation and flexible work policies.
Even in non-unionized sectors, labor market competition and employee demand for work-life balance have pressured employers to limit excessive working hours.
Globalization and outsourcing have increased competitive pressures, leading employers to demand longer hours regardless of union status.
Studies show that countries with strong labor protections (often union-backed) still experience rising working hours due to cultural and economic factors beyond union influence.
